name: 4-hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine
Reason: To predict the melting point for 4-hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine, we'll start with the basic structure of piperidine, which has a melting point of -9°C. Modifications to the piperidine ring will affect this value. Each methyl group (CH3) typically increases the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces. We can estimate this increment at about +5°C per methyl group. There are four methyl groups, so the additive effect would be roughly +20°C. Additionally, the hydroxy group (OH) will drastically increase the melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds with nearby molecules; this could raise the melting point significantly, estimated at about +120°C. Combining these effects, we get an adjusted estimate for the melting point.
